title: Journal Pre-proof Elevated ammonium delays the impairment of the coral-dinoflagellate symbiosis during labile carbon pollution
abstract: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

abstract.text: This is a PDF file of an article that has undergone enhancements after acceptance, such as the addition of a cover page and metadata, and formatting for readability, but it is not yet the definitive version of record. This version will undergo additional copyediting, typesetting and review before it is published in its final form, but we are providing this version to give early visibility of the article. Please note that, during the production process, errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.

body_text.text: Over the last decades, the global coral cover of reef ecosystems has been in decline due to a combination of large scale and local stressors (Hughes et al., 2017a; Pandolfi et al., 2011) .

Driven by climate change, rising sea surface temperatures have triggered unprecedented mass coral bleaching events (Hughes et al., 2017b; Spalding and Brown, 2015) . Bleached corals have lost their primary source of energy due to the loss of algal symbionts (Symbiodiniaceae), and prolonged bleaching periods often lead to high levels of coral mortality (Plass-Johnson et al., 2015) . Climate change in combination with coastal pollution, particularly the input of organic and inorganic nutrients, can exacerbate the detrimental effects of global warming (Wiedenmann et al., 2013) . Coral reefs exposed to high levels of pollution display relatively higher rates of bleaching, coral diseases (Vega Thurber et al., 2014; Zaneveld et al., 2016) and higher relative cover of algae (McManus and Polsenberg, 2004; Nyström et al., 2000) .

Among organic nutrients, the increased availability of labile dissolved organic carbon (DOC) is considered a major contributor to coral mortality and subsequent loss of coral cover (Smith J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f et al., 2006) . As a product of both sewage and algal-derived exudates, elevated labile DOC availability in polluted and/or algal-dominated reefs can have a multifaceted and negative impact on coral health. Labile DOC is highly enriched in easily degradable monosaccharides (i.e. glucose, galactose, mannose, and xylose) which stimulate bacterial growth, particularly that of copiotrophic bacteria and opportunistic pathogens (Nelson et al., 2013) . This microbialization of the coral reef can increase the potential for coral disease by enhancing localized hypoxia, virulence factors, accumulation of poisons (e.g. hydrogen sulphide or secondary metabolites) and pathogenicity (Cárdenas et al., 2018; Haas et al., 2016 Haas et al., , 2011 Kline et al., 2006; Kuntz et al., 2005; Nelson et al., 2013; Smith et al., 2006) . Subsequent coral die-off related to disease creates space for further algal growth, thereby inducing a positive feedback loop summarized in the DDAM (Disease, Dissolved organic carbon, Algae, Microbes) model (Barott and Rohwer, 2012) . A recent study (Pogoreutz et al., 2017) however showed that individual colonies of Pocillopora damicornis displayed severe bleaching in response to elevated levels of DOC despite a stable coral microbiome and the absence of pathogens, suggesting that there might be bacterial-independent effects of DOC on corals.

Although the link between DOC and bleaching via disease has been established, previous studies on terrestrial plants and free-living Symbiodiniaceae cells imply that there may also be differing pathways for increased DOC to affect the coral-algal symbiosis. Exogenous DOC (i.e. sugars) decreases the expression of photosynthetic genes and represses photosynthesis in terrestrial plants (Moore et al., 2003; Pourtau, Jennings, Pelzer, Pallas, & Wingler, 2006; Wingler, Marès, & Pourtau, 2004) . Also, free-living cells of the genus Symbiodinium experienced a dramatically reduced photosynthetic capacity when grown on DOCsupplemented medium (Xiang et al., 2018) . It was suggested that these photosynthetically incompetent free-living algae are also less likely to establish a symbiosis with a coral host (Hagedorn et al., 2015) , but whether labile DOC compounds also have the potential to impair the photosynthetic functioning of the algae in hospite and de-stabilize the coral symbiosis has not been investigated yet.

In DOC-supplemented plants, repression of photosynthesis is not only induced via DOC enrichment per se, but also depends on the level of nitrogen supply. While photosynthesis in nitrogen-limited plants is DOC repressed, there is no loss in photosynthetic activity when the growth medium was additionally supplied with nitrogen (Lobo et al., 2015; Moore et al., 2003; Paul and Driscoll, 1997) . On the contrary to plants, it was suggested that coral bleaching upon DOC enrichment is induced via the increased supply of ammonium from J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f coral-associated N2 fixing bacteria (Pogoreutz et al., 2017) . It was hypothesized that this increased ammonium availability caused the breakdown of the coral symbiosis by inducing an imbalanced nitrogen:phosphorus ratio of the symbionts (Wiedenmann et al., 2013) . Such symbiosis disruption is however not observed with ammonium enrichment alone, which also proved to be very beneficial in avoiding coral bleaching during thermal stress (Béraud et al., 2013; Zhou et al., 2017) . All together, these observations suggest that the role of nitrogen supply during DOC-induced bleaching deserves more attention, both at the symbiont and host level. Whether DOC enrichment induces bleaching by repressing symbiont photosynthesis and/or by replacing the carbon provided by symbiont photosynthates, and whether nitrogen supplementation can mitigate DOC-induced photosynthesis repression remains to be investigated.

Therefore, the aims of the present study were to specifically test the effects of labile DOC pollution in nitrogen-deficient and nitrogen-sufficient corals on 1) the photosynthetic functioning of the algal symbionts, 2) the energy reserves of the coral host and 3) the C:N:P status of host tissue and symbionts. For this purpose, healthy coral colonies of Stylophora pistillata were exposed to ambient and elevated labile DOC levels in combination with ambient and increased ammonium concentrations for a total period of 6 weeks followed by a recovery period of 3 weeks under ambient DOC and ammonium conditions ( Fig. 1 , Table S1 ).

In addition, since DOC enrichment can stimulate coral-associated N2 fixation (Pogoreutz et al., 2017) , we conducted coral incubations with 15 N2-enriched seawater to check whether DOC exposure will supply the corals with additional nitrogen from diazotrophs.

Eight parental colonies of the tropical scleractinian coral species Stylophora pistillata, originating from the Gulf of Aqaba (Northern Red Sea), were used to prepare a total of 112 nubbins (14 nubbins per colony). Nubbins (3 cm in height and 1 cm in diameter) were individually hung on nylon threads and randomly distributed in eight experimental 20 L tanks, leading to 14 nubbins/tank. The tanks received a continuous supply of oligotrophic seawater (<0.5 μM dissolved inorganic nitrogen and <0.2 μM inorganic phosphate) at a flow rate of 20 L h -1 . Seawater temperature (25 ± 0.5°C) and light level (200 μmol photons m -2 s -1 ; 12:12 light:dark) were maintained using submersible resistance heaters (Visi-therm Deluxe, J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Aquarium Systems, France) and metal halide lamps (Philips, HPIT 400 W, Distrilamp, Bossee, France), respectively. Nubbins were acclimated for 5 weeks in these tanks prior to the start of the experiment. Within the first 2 weeks of the acclimation period, corals were fed twice a week with Artemia salina nauplii to improve their recovery from fragmentation.

Feeding was stopped for the remaining 3 weeks of acclimation to minimize confounding effects from organic nutrient uptake during the subsequent experimental period. For the subsequent experimental period, the eight tanks were divided into four treatments with duplicate tanks per treatment ( Fig. 1 ): (i) Control, (ii) nitrogen enriched in the form of ammonium (N), (iii) DOC enriched (DOC), (iv) DOC plus ammonium enriched (DOC+N).

We used a similar aquarium set-up as in (Pogoreutz et al., 2017) with each aquarium tank connected to a 100 L re-circulating water reservoir at a flow rate of 20 L h -1 . 50% of the water in each reservoir tank was renewed on a daily basis and the respective treatment conditions manipulated. Ambient nutrient concentrations were ~0.1 mM DOC and ~0.2 μM ammonium, and were manipulated to final concentrations of 1.0 mM DOC and 4.0 μM ammonium in the enriched tanks by daily additions of a saccharide mixture (19.5% (D+) Galactose, 22.5% (D+) Glucose, 24.5% (D+) Mannose and 33.5% (D+) Xylose) and an ammonium chloride solution (NH4Cl). The % contribution of each saccharide represents the neutral monosaccharide composition of sewage and coral reef macroalgae exudates (Huang et al., 2010; Nelson et al., 2013) . Natural DOC concentrations on coral reefs range on average from 30 to 80 μM (Haas et al., 2016) , while on some reefs pulses of extremely high organic carbon concentrations (>300 μM) have been sporadically (less than 3% of annual measurements) observed (Baker et al., 2007) . The present study followed a mechanistic approach to investigate the effects of DOC enrichment on the coral symbiosis under low and high ammonium availability; in order to compare our results directly with those of Pogoreutz et al. (2017) we applied the same DOC concentrations that were three-fold higher as observed for some reef sites during high organic carbon pulses (Baker et al., 2007) . An enriched ammonium concentration of 4 μM was chosen as it is known to cause significantly increased ammonium uptake rates (120-510 ng N cm -2 h -1 ) in S. pistillata as compared to uptake rates (2-30 ng N cm -2 h -1 ) at 0.2 μM ammonium (Grover et al., 2002) . DOC and ammonium concentrations were monitored once a week in all tanks using an autoanalyser (Alliance Instrument, AMS, France) and TOC analyser (Shimadzu TOC-VCPH; CV maximum ≤1.5 %, i.e. ± 1 μmol C L (Table S1 ). Corals were kept under these four treatment conditions for a total period of 6 weeks (treatment period), followed by a recovery period over 3 weeks in which all tanks were supplied with seawater containing ambient DOC and ammonium concentrations. Before the start of the experiment, DOC (i.e. glucose) assimilation into host tissue and Symbiodiniaceae was tested and quantified on eight extra Control corals using the tracer 13 C-Glucose. During the experiment, a specific number of coral nubbins was sampled from each tank during week 3 and 6 (treatment period) as well as during week 9 (recovery period) for the following measurements: 1) Symbiodiniaceae specific parameters (the maximum quantum yield (Fv/Fm) of photosystem II (PSII), photosynthesis rates, Symbiodiniaceae density and Chl a content); 2) host energy reserves (protein, carbohydrate and lipid content); 3) lipid peroxidation (LPO) as a proxy for ROS production; 4) stoichiometric nutrient ratios (C:N:P) of Symbiodiniaceae and host; 5) activity of N2 fixing microbes (assimilation of diazotrophderived nitrogen by host and symbionts).

Briefly, 13 C-Glucose enriched seawater was prepared by adding 13 C-Glucose powder to a final concentration of 0.3 mM. Coral nubbins were then incubated in 200 ml of both 13 C-Glucose enriched (n=4) and unenriched (n=4) seawater for 2h and 5h. Thereafter, corals were rinsed with unenriched seawater to remove all exogenous 13 C-Glucose. Coral tissue was removed from the skeleton using an water-pick and separated in several centrifugation steps into animal and algal fraction (Grover et al., 2002) . Each fraction was freeze-dried before the 13 C enrichment together with the organic carbon content was quantified using a mass spectrometer (Delta Plus, Thermofisher Scientific, Germany) coupled via a ConFlo III interface to a C/N analyzer (Flash EA, Thermofisher Scientific). The atom % 13 C excess enrichment resulting from glucose assimilation was calculated by subtracting the natural 13 C enrichment obtained from control corals and considered significant when it was at least three times higher as the standard deviation of control samples. Finally, glucose uptake rates were calculated by the following equation (van Oevelen et al., 2016) :
Glucose uptake = [atom % 13 Cexcess / (t x atom % 13 Cincubation water)] x [μg PCsample / cm 2 ],

where t is the incubation time, atom % 13 Cincubation water is the 13 C enrichment of the glucose J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f pool in the 13 C enriched incubation water and PCsample / cm 2 is the particulate carbon content of the sample at the end of the incubation normalized per cm 2 coral skeletal surface area.

The Fv/Fm of the algal symbionts was measured once a week on four coral fragments per tank (n=8 per treatment) using a pulse amplitude modulation (PAM) fluorometer (DIVING-PAM, Walz, Germany). Measurements were conducted in the early morning on dark-adapted coral fragments.

Oxygen flux measurements were conducted to assess net photosynthesis (Pn) and dark respiration (R) rates of the coral fragments during week 3 and 6 of the treatment period and at the end of the recovery period. Two nubbins per tank (n=4 per treatment and time point) were incubated under constant stirring in a thermally regulated 50 ml beaker completely filled with 0.45 μm filtered seawater. Oxygen fluxes were monitored over 60 min (in 1 min intervals) in the dark (R rates) and at 200 μmol quanta m -2 s -1 (Pn rates), respectively, using Unisense optodes connected to a computer with OXY-4 software (Chanel fiber-optic oxygen meter, PreSens, Germany). Optodes were calibrated against N2-saturated and air-saturated seawater for 0% and 100% oxygen saturation, respectively. P n and R rates were calculated by regressing oxygen data against time and normalizing the rates to both, incubation volume and skeletal surface area (cm 2 ) of the coral fragment. Skeletal surface area of the coral fragments was determined using the single wax-dipping technique (Veal et al., 2010) . Gross photosynthesis (Pg) was subsequently calculated according to Pg = Pn -R. Additionally, Pg was converted into carbon equivalent (Pc) in order to compare the carbon input from 13 C-Glucose uptake with that from photosynthesis. The daily carbon input from Pc and glucose uptake was calculated using a 12h (i.e. light period) and 24h period, respectively. Since the heterotrophic uptake of glucose is supposed to be primarily assimilated by the host rather than the Symbiodiniaceae, we calculated the individual amount of photosynthesis-derived carbon available to the host (Pchost) and symbionts (Pcsymbiont) assuming that ca. 80% of total Pc is translocated to the host and 20% is kept by symbionts (Tremblay et al., 2014) .
At the end of each incubation during week 3, 6 and 9 of the experiment, coral fragments were frozen at -80°C for the determination of Symbiodiniaceae and host tissue specific parameters.

The coral tissue was removed from the skeleton. Symbiodiniaceae density was quantified on a Coulter Counter (Beckman Coulter, France) and chlorophyll concentrations were determined following a spectrophotometric method (Jeffrey and Humphrey, 1975) . The total protein content was assessed according to Smith et al. (1985) by the use of a BCAssay Protein Quantification Kit (Uptima, Interchim) and a Xenius spectrofluorometer (SAFAS, Monaco).
body_text.section: J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

body_text.text: At the end of week 3, an additional set of coral fragments from each treatment (n=4) was frozen at -80°C. Each fragment was cut into three little pieces for the separate determination of total lipids, carbohydrates and lipid peroxidation (LPO). Total lipids were extracted from each coral sample twice in a 2:1 dichloromethane:methanol solution followed by stirring and ultrasonication for 10 min. The lipid extracts were collected after centrifugation (2000g; 10 min), filtered and washed with dichloromethane and water (1:1). The liquid was evaporated and the two aliquots from both extractions were pooled for gravimetric quantification of the dried lipid extracts. Carbohydrates were quantified based on the phenol-sulfuric acid method (Dubois et al., 1956 ) by using a Total Carbohydrate Assay Kit (Sigma-Aldrich) with glucose as a standard. All tissue parameters were normalized to the skeletal surface area (cm 2 ) of the coral sample.
body_text.section: J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

body_text.text: The peroxidative damage to lipids as a proxy for oxidative stress was quantified using the TBARS assay (Oakes and van der Kraak, 2003) . Briefly, malondialdehyde (MDA), a byproduct of LPO, reacts with thiobarbituric acid (TBA) and generates a chromogen that can be quantified via spectrofluorometry (excitation: 512 nm; emission: 553 nm). LPO was standardized to the protein content in the coral sample homogenate and expressed as nmol MDA μg -1 Protein.
body_text.section: J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f

body_text.text: Briefly, during week 3 two coral fragments per tank (n=4 per treatment) were incubated over 24h in 500 ml gas-tight glass bottles completely filled with 450 ml seawater (0.2 μm filtered) and 50 ml 15 N2 enriched seawater. 15 N2 enriched seawater was produced prior to the incubation experiment by injecting 10 ml of 15 N2 gas (98 % Eurisotop) into degassed 0.2 μm filtered seawater. Additional coral fragments (n=4 per treatment) incubated without 15 N2enriched seawater served as controls. After the incubation, the coral tissue was removed from the skeleton using an air-pik and separated in several centrifugation steps into animal and algal fraction (Grover et al., 2002) . In order to also determine the C:N:P ratio on these samples, each fraction was divided into two aliquots. The first aliquot was freeze-dried and the atom % 15 N enrichment together with the organic carbon and nitrogen content was J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f determined using a mass spectrometer (Delta Plus, Thermofisher Scientific, Germany) coupled via a ConFlo III interface to a C/N analyzer (Flash EA, Thermofisher Scientific).

The second aliquot was ashed (2 h, 500 °C) in Pyrex containers, acidified with 5 ml 0.2 M HCl and incubated for 45 min at 500 °C (Godinot et al., 2011) before phosphorus was measured on a spectrophotometer according to (Murphy and Riley, 1962) . The total organic carbon, nitrogen and phosphorus content was calculated per sample to determine the respective C:N and N:P ratios.
Statistical analysis was performed using R v3.2.2 (R Development Core Team, 2015).
Univariate two-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was used to test the effects of DOC and ammonium exposure on each physiological response parameter at each time-point (week 3,

week 6, week 9) of the experiment. All data were checked before to meet the assumptions for parametric tests using Levene's test (homogeneity of variances) and Bartlett test (normal distribution). Tukey HSD was used as post hoc analysis for multiple comparisons between treatments with a significance level of p<0.05. The 13 C ( 13 C-glucose uptake experiment) and
15 N ( 15 N2 incubation experiments) enrichments of corals incubated with and without isotope tracers were compared using individual Student's t-tests.

Corals exposed to elevated DOC concentrations in combination with low ammonium availability experienced significant changes of Symbiodiniaceae and host-specific parameters as compared to Control corals. After 3 weeks of treatment the density and pigmentation (Chl a) of Symbiodiniaceae were significantly reduced accompanied by a significant decline in Pg rates and Fv/Fm (Fig. 2, Fig. 3 , Table S2 ). The Fv/Fm responded quickly to the DOC treatment starting to decline within the first week of treatment. DOC treated corals were overall net heterotrophic (Pg:R ratio < 1) as compared to net autotrophic (Pg:R ratio > 1)
body_text.section: Effects of DOC enrichment under low ammonium availability

body_text.text: Control corals (Fig. S1 ). Also after 6 weeks of treatment these above mentioned Symbiodiniaceae-specific parameters remained significantly reduced as compared to Control corals.
body_text.section: Effects of DOC enrichment under low ammonium availability

body_text.text: The coral host experienced a significantly increased carbohydrate but stable lipid and protein contents as compared to Control corals after 3 weeks of DOC treatment (Fig. 3, 4) . While the J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f host protein content remained stable after 3 weeks of treatment, it significantly decreased in DOC-treated corals as compared to Controls after 6 weeks indicating an increased use of nitrogen reserves by the host. The 13 C-glucose incubation of Control corals in our preexperiment confirmed that the coral host (10.2±2.3 μg C cm -2 d -1 ) primarily assimilates DOC (i.e. glucose) from seawater as compared to Symbiodiniaceae (0.7±0.2 μg C cm -2 d -1 ) ( Table   1 , Table S3 ). The calculated Pchost of Control corals was 97±11 μg C cm -2 d -1 (during week 3) indicating that glucose assimilation by the host can provide an additional 10% of carbon to the host's total carbon budget. Assuming a stable glucose uptake among treatments, glucose may contribute more importantly to the host's carbon budget when Pchost is reduced to 22±13 μg C cm -2 d -1 in DOC treated corals during week 3.
body_text.section: Effects of DOC enrichment under low ammonium availability

body_text.text: The LPO assay as proxy for ROS production showed no differences in MDA levels between DOC-treated and Control corals after 3 weeks of treatment (Fig. 4) . The 15 N2 incubation resulted in similar 15 N enrichments of both Control and DOC treated corals, indicating that corals were not supplemented with diazotrophically-derived nitrogen during the experiment (Table S4 ). The stoichiometric nutrient ratios (C:N and N:P) of both, host tissue and symbionts, were also not affected by the DOC treatment (Fig. S2, Table S5 ).
body_text.section: Effects of DOC enrichment under low ammonium availability

body_text.text: Corals exposed to elevated DOC concentrations in combination with high ammonium availability (DOC+N) responded differently as compared to DOC enrichment under low ammonium availability. After 3 weeks of treatment corals exposed to DOC+N revealed a stable Symbiodiniaceae density and stable Pg rates as compared to Control corals, and the pigmentation content (Chl a) significantly increased similar to N-treated corals (Fig. 3 , Table   S2 ). Despite stable Pg rates DOC+N treated corals were net heterotrophic (Pg:R ratio < 1) due to increased R rates as compared to Control corals. (Fig. S1 ). The Fv/Fm remained stable for the first 2 weeks of treatment, while it decreased starting only in week 3 (Fig. 2) . After 6 weeks of treatment, DOC+N treated corals showed significantly reduced symbiont densities, Chl a contents and Pg rates accompanied by a further decline in Fv/Fm as compared to Control corals while these Symbiodiniaceae-specific parameters remained stable and elevated in N treated corals. The host-specific parameters (i.e. carbohydrate and lipid content) of DOC+N treated corals remained stable after 3 weeks of treatment as compared to Control corals (Fig. 4) . The protein content of N and DOC+N treated corals increased after 3 weeks as compared to Controls, but no differences between these three treatments occurred after 6 weeks indicating overall maintenance of nitrogen reserves by the host. Similar to the DOC J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f treatment, the stoichiometric nutrient ratios (C:N and N:P) of both host tissue and Symbiodiniaceae were not affected by the DOC+N treatment (Fig. S2 , Table S5 ) and no supplementation with diazotrophically-derived nitrogen was detected (Table S4) . LPO was not affected neither in the N nor DOC+N treatment after 3 weeks (Fig. 4) .
body_text.section: Effects of DOC enrichment under high ammonium availability

body_text.text: After 3 weeks recovery from DOC enrichment, the Symbiodiniaceae density and the areal Chl a content remained still significantly reduced in both DOC and DOC+N as compared to Control corals (Fig. 3, Table S2 ). However, the Chl a content per Symbiodiniaceae cell and the Fv/Fm fully recovered to values similar to Control corals. While the DOC corals were still net heterotrophic (Pg:R ratio < 1) with lower Pg rates as compared to Control corals, DOC+N corals completely recovered their Pg and were again net autotrophic. The reduced protein content of DOC corals was fully recovered after 3 weeks indicating that the host restored its nitrogen reserves.

In coral holobionts, photosynthetically competent Symbiodiniaceae cells along with a successful transfer of photosynthates to the coral host are key to the health and survival of reef-building corals in tropical oligotrophic waters (Tremblay et al., 2012) . Our results demonstrate that elevated DOC levels in the seawater in combination with low ammonium availability impaired the photosynthetic functioning of Symbiodiniaceae in hospite indicated by decreased Fv/Fm, Chl a levels and Pg rates. Interestingly, photosynthetic parameters recovered once the DOC exposure ceased. The decline and subsequent recovery of photosynthesis in response to elevated and ambient DOC levels, respectively, indicates that exogenous DOC supply may directly affect the photosynthetic functioning of the endosymbiotic algae.
body_text.section: DOC deteriorates the photosynthetic functioning of Symbiodiniaceae in hospite

body_text.text: Although the molecular mechanisms behind the DOC-induced loss in photosynthetic activity are not completely understood, studies on plants demonstrate that it is related to a strong decrease in abundance, activation state and activity of ribulose-1,5-bisphosphate carboxylase/oxygenase (RuBisCo), the enzyme catalyzing the first step of the Calvin cycle (Lobo et al., 2015; Oesterhelt et al., 2007) . A reduced RuBisCo activity and synthesis will disrupt the photosynthetic 'dark reaction' thereby reducing the amount of available electron acceptors (ADPi and NADP + ) which will saturate the electron chain of the 'light reaction' (Takahashi and Murata, 2008) . Subsequently, this can trigger the onset of photoinhibition by damaging components of photosystem II and generating reactive oxygen species (ROS).
body_text.section: DOC deteriorates the photosynthetic functioning of Symbiodiniaceae in hospite

body_text.text: Although we did not measure RuBisCo abundance in these corals, we quantified LPO, a process that is generally enhanced during increased ROS production (Lesser, 2006) . In corals, symbiont expulsion is often the consequence to prevent further ROS-related cell damage (Lesser, 1997) . Here, we observed a ~50% Symbiodiniaceae loss after 3 weeks of DOC enrichment, while no difference in the amount of LPO was detected between DOC-treated and Control corals. This indicates that the reduced photosynthetic efficiency and subsequent expulsion of Symbiodiniaceae cells in response to DOC enrichment is possibly not due to ROS-induced cellular damage. The fast recovery of the photosynthetic efficiency once the DOC exposure ended also indicates that photosystem II was rather inactivated than damaged.
body_text.section: DOC deteriorates the photosynthetic functioning of Symbiodiniaceae in hospite

body_text.text: ROS levels can however be very dynamic in stressed corals and more frequent measurements would be required over the course of an experiment to clearly verify the role of ROS during Previous work (Xiang et al., 2018) has shown that free-living Symbiodinium cells (SSB01) also displayed decreased PSII and PSI activities accompanied by pigmentation loss, thylakoid fragmentation and a change in cell surface morphology when grown on glucose-supplemented medium. These Symbiodinium cells recovered their PSII activity once returned to medium without sugar supply (Xiang et al., 2018) , similar to the observations of our corals during the recovery period. These findings show that Symbiodinium cells can switch its carbon metabolism from photoautotrophic nutrition to mixotrophic or heterotrophic nutrition when supplied with glucose. While changes in the carbon metabolism, particularly the loss of photosynthetic activity, in response to DOC enrichment may not affect the survival of freeliving Symbiodinium cells, it may have severe implications to establish and/or maintain a symbiotic association with a cnidarian host. Indeed, a reduced capacity to populate and establish a symbiosis with a cnidarian host was observed for free-living Symbiodinium cells that previously lost their photosynthetic activity in response to exogenous glucose (Hagedorn et al., 2015; Xiang et al., 2018) . This was likely driven by the absence of photosynthesisderived carbon (i.e. trehalose), that serves as chemoattractant for coral larvae indicating that the algae are photosynthetically competent (Hagedorn et al., 2015) . Similarly, in an established and intact coral symbiosis, Symbiodiniaceae likely signal their photosynthetic competency by constantly translocating photosynthates to the host. As suggested in the arrested phagosome hypothesis the symbiosome may mimick a prey digesting phagosome via constant photosynthate translocation that allows residence within the intracellular host cell habitat (Hill and Hill, 2012); on the contrary, when photosynthate translocation drops below host cellular expectations, symbionts may be detected by the host followed by digestion/exocytosis via phago-lysosome fusion (Hill and Hill, 2012) . Besides a loss of photosynthetic activity, changes in the cell-surface morphology and thylakoid fragmentation have also been observed on Symbiodinium cells grown on elevated external sugar levels (Xiang et al., 2018) . The surface structure of Symbiodinium cells can be critical for interactions with a cnidarian host as surface differences of glucose-grown cells reduced host infection of Aiptasia larvae (Xiang et al., 2018) . Also, thylakoid breakdown can trigger the autophagic-associated machinery of host cells resulting in digestion/exocytosis of symbionts (Downs et al., 2009) .
body_text.section: DOC deteriorates the photosynthetic functioning of Symbiodiniaceae in hospite

body_text.text: The role of inorganic nitrogen availability on coral performance and on the coraldinoflagellate symbiosis is still poorly understood (Ezzat et al., 2016; Wiedenmann et al., 2013) . The general view is that elevated nitrogen availability can disrupt the nitrogen-limited state in which corals maintain their dinoflagellate symbionts, leading to an uncontrolled symbiont proliferation and decreased photosynthate translocation at the detriment of the host (Koop et al., 2001; Marubini and Davies, 1996; Stambler et al., 1991) . However, more recent studies show that the effects of nitrogen (i.e. ammonium) enrichment are rather beneficial to corals (Ezzat et al., 2015; Shantz and Burkepile, 2014) .

Here, the decrease in Fv/Fm, Pg rates, Symbiodiniaceae densities and Chl a contents was significantly delayed when DOC-treated corals were additionally supplied with elevated ammonium levels in the seawater (i.e. DOC+N treatment). All Symbiodiniaceae-related parameters in DOC+N treated corals remained stable for an extended period, and only declined after 6 weeks of treatment. Since photosynthetic parameters in corals only supplemented with additional ammonium (i.e. N treatment) were stable throughout the entire experiment, we can rule out that corals were negatively impacted by ammonium enrichment itself. Overall, the data demonstrate that ammonium supply can effectively mitigate the negative effects of DOC enrichment on the maintenance of the coral symbiosis for a limited period of time. Similar effects have been observed on higher plants where additional nitrogen supplementation diminished the negative effects of exogenous sugars by helping the plant to maintain photosynthetic gene expression, RuBisCo activity, pigmentation and overall photosynthetic activity (Martin et al., 2002; Paul and Driscoll, 1997) . Similarly to higher plants, ammonium enrichment was demonstrated to cause early transcriptional changes in a reef-building coral including an up-regulation in the expression of RuBisCo and Chl a-J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f binding protein genes (Rosic et al., 2014) . Also, in thermally stressed corals ammonium stimulates the production of photosynthetic and photoprotective pigments, thereby maintaining the photophysiological capacity and preventing bleaching of corals (Béraud et al., 2013 ). Since ammonium can decrease the susceptibility of corals to temperature-induced bleaching, similar mechanisms may explain the beneficial role of ammonium in mitigating DOC-induced bleaching.

Although we clearly demonstrate that ammonium has the potential to delay DOC-induced bleaching, a previous study observed bleaching in response to DOC stress despite an increased nitrogen supply from N2 fixing bacteria (Pogoreutz et al., 2017) . In the presence of similar DOC loadings between the two studies, a different amount of ammonium supply to the corals may explain these contrasting results. In the present study ammonium uptake rates were approximately 120-510 ng N cm -2 h -1 as compared to only ~14 ng N cm -2 h -1 (2 nmol C2H4 cm -2 h -1 ; using a theoretical 4:1 (C2H4:N2) conversion ratio) in (Pogoreutz et al., 2017) .

Also, the contrasting effects of ammonium enrichment during DOC-induced bleaching could have been driven by a different nitrogen to phosphorus (N:P) ratio within the coral symbionts. Pogoreutz et al. (2017) measured increased N:P ratios in Symbiodiniaceae of DOC-treated corals. The bleaching susceptibility of corals is known to increase during an imbalanced N:P supply. However, bleaching upon N enrichment is in this case explained by rather extremely low P than surplus N availabilities (Wiedenmann et al., 2013) . In our study, P availability was possibly sufficient (~0.2 μM) throughout the experiment as no bleaching occurred in the treatment only supplied with N. Also, stable nutrient stoichiometries (C:N and N:P ratios) among all treatments suggest that an N:P imbalance was likely not the main driver for DOCinduced bleaching. Overall, our study indicates that N enrichment enables Symbiodiniaceae cells to maintain their photosynthetic competency over a longer period, which may explain why symbiont expulsion was significantly delayed in the DOC+N as compared to the DOC treatment.

Although we showed that DOC enrichment has detrimental effects on the photosynthetic capacity of coral symbionts and the maintenance of the coral-algae association, DOC may instead benefit the heterotrophic coral host metabolism by serving as alternative carbon J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f source. Coral host cells more heavily rely on their stored energy reserves when carbon translocation from symbionts is reduced under bleached conditions. This energy is primarily obtained through ATP utilization, followed by the depletion of available glucose reserves, and finally through the activation of lipid hydrolysis. Depletion of total lipids is a well-established phenomenon in corals starting within a few days after the onset of bleaching (Anthony et al., 2009; Imbs and Yakovleva, 2012; Rodrigues and Grottoli, 2007) . The use of lipid reserves by the host can vary in accordance with the coral colony morphology (Yamashiro et al., 2005) , the size of initial lipid stores (Anthony et al., 2009) and the heterotrophic capacity of the coral host (Grottoli et al., 2006) . Moreover, it may also depend on the availability of alternative carbon sources such as DOC in the surrounding seawater. Our results show that DOC-treated corals maintained their total lipid content and even increased their carbohydrate content despite 50% symbiont loss. We demonstrate using 13 C-glucose that corals assimilate DOC from the seawater primarily into the host tissue, which can account in Control corals for 10% of the host's carbon supply derived from photosynthesis (Pchost). This amount of glucose uptake can become more important for the total carbon budget of the host, when Pchost is reduced by 75% in DOC-treated corals. The uptake and metabolic utilization of exogenous DOC can thus help corals to partially replace the reduced autotrophic carbon input and to conserve their carbon reserves during bleaching. Also previous studies have shown that DOC can be a source for some coral species to maintain their carbon budgets when bleached in response to elevated sea surface temperature (Levas et al., 2016 (Levas et al., , 2013 . However, heterotrophic uptake of DOC in repeatedly bleached corals failed to mitigate carbon budget deficits of the host likely due to a lack of heterotrophic plasticity (Levas et al., 2016) .
body_text.section: DOC as alternative energy source for bleached corals

body_text.text: Interestingly, only DOC-treated corals showed an increased carbohydrate content in the tissue, while no increase occurred for DOC+N treated corals. Assuming similar DOC assimilation rates between these two treatments, different carbohydrate contents may be explained by differences in the metabolic activities of corals. Indeed, DOC-treated corals had lower respiration rates compared to DOC+N treated corals, indicating a reduced metabolic activity that possibly allows bleached DOC-treated colonies to better conserve energy reserves. Although no depletion in carbon reserves (i.e. lipids, carbohydrates) was observed in bleached DOC-treated corals, the protein content significantly decreased indicating that the host catabolizes its own nitrogen reserves. In contrast, the corals' nitrogen reserves (i.e. protein) remained stable when exposed to DOC+N. Overall, our results suggest that bleached corals may rely on external DOC for a limited period of time, whereas the provision of additional nitrogen will be essential to avoid long-term depletion of nitrogen reserves within J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f the host tissue. Lastly, it should be noted that the present study followed a mechanistic approach by investigating the effects of relatively high DOC and ammonium concentrations on the coral symbiosis. Although our study alerts on the potential risk of high DOC levels for coral physiology, further studies will be needed to determine the effects under environmentally relevant DOC conditions as well as under chronic DOC exposure over longer time periods.
body_text.section: DOC as alternative energy source for bleached corals

body_text.text: Coastal pollution and overfishing are the primary local cause for reef degradation due to benthic community shifts from calcifying organisms to non-calcifying algae (Nyström et al., 2000) . Exudates from turfing algae and fleshy macroalgae increase the availability of labile DOC in reef waters that can harm and/or kill corals through favoring the growth of copiotrophic and pathogenic microbes (Kline et al., 2006; Nelson et al., 2013) . In addition to this microbial-mediated DOC effect on corals, the present study demonstrates that DOC pollution can also directly impair the photosynthetic functioning of Symbiodiniaceae in hospite thereby de-stabilizing the maintenance of the coral symbiosis. Although DOC may serve as alternative carbon source for the host when the availability of photosynthesis-derived carbon is reduced, we show that other key nutrients (i.e. nitrogen) are particularly essential to maintain coral symbionts in a photosynthetically competent state, to conserve the host's energy reserves and subsequently to delay DOC-induced bleaching.

Poor water quality in combination with global climate change is also known to lower the resistance of corals to extreme thermal anomalies (Wiedenmann et al., 2013) and to increase the likelihood of coral disease outbreaks (Maynard et al., 2015) . Therefore, local reef management strategies seeking to improve the resilience of coral reefs must 1) reduce coastal anthropogenic nutrient input, and 2) additionally increase herbivorous fish standing stocks can help to control algal growth while also contributing to beneficial nutrients (i.e. ammonium) for corals. This can help minimize environmental impacts associated with the global challenge of climate change.

Pc assimilated by the coral host (Pchost) and Symbiodiniaceae (Pcsymbiont) were calculated by converting Pg oxygen fluxes into carbon equivalents and assuming that 80% of this photosynthetically fixed carbon is translocated from the symbionts to the host and 20% is kept by the symbionts (Tremblay et al., 2014) . All values are given as mean ± SD.

FIGREF4.text: While previous studies focused on DOC effects during the initial establishment of the cnidarian-algae symbiosis, the present study expands the current knowledge showing that theJ o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f maintenance of an already established symbiotic association is also impaired under DOC enrichment. Overall, the reduced photosynthetic activity accompanied with a potentially modified membrane structure of symbionts upon DOC enrichment may have possibly induced symbiont expulsion as observed here. Although our results clearly show that sufficient quantities of DOC in the seawater inactivate symbiont photosynthesis, the responsible mechanisms behind symbiont expulsion require further investigation.

FIGREF7.text: Overview of experimental design. Coral fragments were distributed across four treatments (Control, N, DOC and DOC+N) containing either ambient or elevated DOC and ammonium concentrations in the seawater. Corals were kept under these treatment conditions for 6 weeks (treatment period), before coral recovery under ambient DOC and ammonium conditions was followed over 3 subsequent weeks (recovery period).

FIGREF8.text: o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f Photosynthetic efficiencies (Fv/Fm) of Stylophora pistillata corals during the course of the experiment. Fv/Fm was monitored once a week in corals exposed to the different treatments(Control, N, DOC, DOC+N)during the entire course of the experiment (6 treatment weeks followed by 3 recovery weeks).

FIGREF9.text: Physiological parameters of Stylophora pistillata during the treatment and subsequent recovery period. Parameters including Symbiodiniaceae density, areal chlorophyll a content, chlorophyll a content per Symbiodiniaceae cell, protein content, gross photosynthesis (Pg) and photosynthesis to respiration ratio (Pg :R) were measured in corals from the different treatments (Control, N, DOC and DOC+N) during week 3 and 6 (treatment period) and during week 9 (recovery period) of the experiment. Different lettering above the bars indicates significant differences between the treatments based on two-factorial ANOVAs with pairwise TukeyHSD as post-hoc test (significance level, p<0.05).

FIGREF10.text: Carbohydrate and lipid content, lipid peroxidation and images of Stylophora pistillata from the different treatments (Control, N, DOC and DOC+N) during treatment week 3.
